segment.tip: 他们用结实的网把海床搜索了一遍。当一只箱子从海底被打捞上来时、甲板上人们激动不已。
segment.a: The sea bed was scoured with powerful nets and there was tremendous excitement on board when a chest was raised from the bottom.

segment.tip: 船员们开始认为沉船找着了，但海底沉箱内的物品证明他们弄错了。
segment.a: Though the crew were at first under the impression that the lost ship had been found, the contents of the chest proved them wrong.

segment.tip: 事实上他们发现的是另一艘沉没多年的船。
segment.a: What they had in fact found was a ship which had been sunk many years before.

segment.tip: 木箱内装有水手艾伦·菲尔丁的私人财物，
segment.a: The chest contained the personal belongings of a seaman, Alan Fielding.

segment.tip: 其中有书籍、衣服、照片以及水手收到的妻子的来信。
segment.a: There were books, clothing and photographs, together with letters which the seaman had once received from his wife.

segment.tip: “埃尔科”号船长命令船员尽量从沉船中打捞物品，
segment.a: The captain of the Elkor ordered his men to salvage as much as possible from the wreck.

segment.tip: 但没发现什么值钱的东西，不过打捞出来的众多的物品还是引起了大家极大的兴趣。
segment.a: Nothing of value was found, but the numerous items which were brought to the surface proved to be of great interest.

segment.tip: 从捞起的一门大炮来看，船长认为那艘船一定是艘巡洋舰。
segment.a: From a heavy gun that was raised, the captain realized that the ship must have been a cruiser.

segment.tip: 另一只海底沉箱中装的是船上一位军官的财物，其中有-一封写于1943年3月14日的信，但没有写完。
segment.a: In another chest, which contained the belongings of a ship's officer, there was an unfinished letter which had been written on March 14th, 1943.

segment.tip: 从这封信中船长了解到沉船船名是“卡伦”号。
segment.a: The captain learnt from the letter that the name of the lost ship was the Karen.

segment.tip: 打捞到的东西中最有价值的是船上的航海日志，其中有一部分仍然清晰可读。
segment.a: The most valuable find of all was the ship's log book, parts of which it was still possible to read.

segment.tip: 据此，船长可以将所有的那些已经搞清的材料拼凑起来。
segment.a: From this the captain was able to piece together all the information that had come to light.

segment.tip: “卡伦”号当年在为其他船只护航驶往俄国途中突然遭到敌方潜水艇鱼雷的袭击。
segment.a: The Karen had been sailing in a convoy to Russia when she was torpedoed by an enemy submarine.

segment.tip: 这一说法在“埃尔科”号返航后得到国防部一位海军官员的证实。
segment.a: This was later confirmed by naval official at the Ministry of Defiance after the Elkor had returned home.

segment.tip: 那次打捞到的所有物品均被送往军事博物馆。
segment.a: All the items that were found were sent to the War Museum.

segment.tip: 我们大家都有过事事不顺心的日子。
segment.a: We have all experienced days when everything goes wrong.

segment.tip: 一天开始时，可能还不错，但突然间似乎一切都失去了控制。
segment.a: A day may begin well enough, but suddenly everything seems to get out of control.

segment.tip: 情况经常是这样的，许许多多的事情都偏偏赶在同一时刻出问题，
segment.a: What invariably happens is that a great number of things choose to go wrong at precisely the same moment.

segment.tip: 好像是一件无关紧要的小事引起了一连串的连锁反应。
segment.a: It is as if a single unimportant event set up a chain of reactions.

segment.tip: 假设你在做饭，同时又在照看孩子。
segment.a: Let us suppose that you are preparing a meal and keeping an eye on the baby at the same time.

segment.tip: 这时电话铃响了。它预示着一连串意想不到的灾难的来临。
segment.a: The telephone rings and this marks the prelude to an unforeseen series of catastrophes.

segment.tip: 就在你接电话时，孩子把桌布从桌子上扯下来，将家中最好的陶瓷餐具半数摔碎，同时也弄伤了他自己。
segment.a: While you are on the phone, the baby pulls the tablecloth off the table, smashing half your best crockery and cutting himself in the process.

segment.tip: 你急急忙忙挂上电话，赶去照看孩子和餐具。
segment.a: You hang up hurriedly and attend to baby, crockery, etc.

segment.tip: 这时，饭又烧糊了。
segment.a: Meanwhile, the meal gets burnt.

segment.tip: 好像这一切还不足以使你急得掉泪，你的丈夫接着回来了，事先没打招呼就带来3个客人吃饭。
segment.a: As if this were not enough to reduce you to tears, your husband arrives, unexpectedly bringing three guests to dinner.

segment.tip: 就像许多人最近在悉尼郊区帕拉马塔发现的那样，有时乱子会闹得很大。
segment.a: Things can go wrong on a big scale, as a number of people recently discovered in Parramatta, a suburb of Sydney.

segment.tip: 一天傍晚交通最拥挤时，一辆汽车撞上前面一辆汽车，两个司机争吵起来。
segment.a: During the rush hour one evening two cars collided and both drivers began to argue.

segment.tip: 紧跟其后的一辆车上的司机碰巧是个初学者，
segment.a: The woman immediately behind the two cars happened to be a learner.

segment.tip: 她一惊之下突然把车停了下来。
segment.a: She suddenly got into a panic and stopped her car.

segment.tip: 她这一停使得跟在后头的司机也来个急刹车。
segment.a: This made the driver following her brake hard.

segment.tip: 司机妻子正坐在他身边，手里托着块大蛋糕。
segment.a: His wife was sitting beside him holding a large cake.

segment.tip: 她往前一冲，蛋糕从挡风玻璃飞了出去掉到马路上。 \n 直译： 当她被抛向前时，蛋糕直接穿过了挡风玻璃，落在了路上。
segment.a: As she was thrown forward, the cake went right through the windscreen and landed on the road.

segment.tip: 此时，一辆卡车正好从后边开到那辆汽车边上，司机看见一块蛋糕从天而降，紧急刹车。 。 \n 直译： 看到一个蛋糕在空中飞过，一个正靠近汽车的卡车司机突然停了下来。
segment.a: Seeing a cake flying through the air, a lorry driver who was drawing up alongside the car, pulled up all of a sudden.

segment.tip: 卡车上装着空啤酒瓶。成百只瓶子顺势从卡车后面滑出车外落在马路上。
segment.a: The lorry was loaded with empty beer bottles and hundreds of them slid off the back of the vehicle and on to the road.

segment.tip: 这又引起一场唇枪舌剑的争吵。
segment.a: This led to yet another angry argument.

segment.tip: 与此同时，后面的车辆排成了长龙，
segment.a: Meanwhile, the traffic piled up behind.

segment.tip: 警察花了将近一个小时才使车辆又开起来。
segment.a: It took the police nearly an hour to get the traffic on the move again.

segment.tip: 在这段时间里，卡车司机不得不清扫那几百只破瓶子。
segment.a: In the meantime, the lorry driver had to sweep up hundreds of broken bottles.

segment.tip: 只有两只野狗从这一片混乱中得到好处，它们贪婪地吃掉了剩下的蛋糕。
segment.a: Only two stray dogs benefited from all this confusion, for they greedily devoured what was left of the cake.

segment.tip: 这就是事事不顺心的那么一天！
segment.a: It was just one of those days!

segment.tip: 古玩店对许多人来说有一种特殊的魅力。
segment.a: Antique shops exert a peculiar fascination on a great many people.

segment.tip: 高档一点的古玩店为了防尘，把文物漂亮地陈列在玻璃柜子里，那里往往令人望而却步。
segment.a: The more expensive kind of antique shop where rare objects are beautifully displayed in glass cases to keep them free from dust is usually a forbidding place.

segment.tip: 而对不太装腔作势的古玩店，无论是谁都不用壮着胆子才敢往里进。
segment.a: But no one has to muster up courage to enter a less pretentious antique shop.

segment.tip: 人们还常常有希望在发霉、阴暗、杂乱无章、迷宫般的店堂里，从杂乱地摆放在地面上的、一堆堆各式各样的破烂货里找到一件稀世珍品。
segment.a: There is always hope that in its labyrinth of musty, dark, disordered rooms a real rarity will be found amongst the piles of assorted junk that little the floors.

segment.tip: 无论是谁都不会一下子就发现一件珍品。
segment.a: No one discovers a rarity by chance.

segment.tip: 一个到处找便宜的人必须具有耐心，而且最重要的是看到珍品时要有鉴别珍品的能力。
segment.a: A truly dedicated bargain hunter must have patience, and above all, the ability to recognize the worth of something when he sees it.

segment.tip: 要做到这一点，他至少要像古董商一样懂行。
segment.a: To do this, he must be at least as knowledgeable as the dealer.

segment.tip: 他必须像一个专心致志进行探索的科学家那样抱有这样的希望，即终有一天，他的努力会取得丰硕的成果。
segment.a: Like a scientist bent on making a discovery, he must cherish the hope that one day he will be amply rewarded.

segment.tip: 我的老朋友弗兰克.哈利戴正是这样一个人。
segment.a: My old friend, Frank Halliday, is just such a person.

segment.tip: 他多次向我详细讲他如何只花50英镑便买到一位名家的杰作。
segment.a: He has often described to me how he picked up a masterpiece for a mere ￡50.

segment.tip: 一个星期六的上午，弗兰克去了我家附近的一家古玩店。
segment.a: One Saturday morning, Frank visited an antique shop in my neighbourhood.

segment.tip: 由于他从未去过那儿，结果他发现许多有趣的东西。
segment.a: As he had never been there before, he found a great deal to interest him.

segment.tip: 上午很快过去了，弗兰克正准备离去，突然看见地板上放着一只体积很大的货箱。
segment.a: The morning passed rapidly and Frank was about to leave when he noticed a large packing case lying on the floor.

segment.tip: 古董商告诉他那只货箱刚到不久，但他嫌麻烦不想把它打开。
segment.a: The dealer told him that it had just come in but that he could not be bothered to open it.

segment.tip: 经弗兰克恳求，古董商才勉强把货箱撬开了。
segment.a: Frank begged him to do so and the dealer reluctantly prised it open.

segment.tip: 箱内东西令人失望。
segment.a: The contents were disappointing.

segment.tip: 除了一柄式样别致、雕有花纹的匕首外，货箱内装满陶器，而且大部分都已破碎裂。
segment.a: Apart from an interesting-looking carved dagger, the box was full of crockery, much of it broken.

segment.tip: 弗兰克轻轻地把陶器拿出箱子，突然发现在箱底有一幅微型画，
segment.a: Frank gently lifted the crockery out of the box an suddenly noticed a miniature painting at the bottom of the packing case.

segment.tip: 画面构图与纸条使他想起一幅他所熟悉的意大利画，于是他决定将画买了下来。
segment.a: As its composition and line reminded him of an Italian painting he knew well, he decided to buy it.

segment.tip: 古董商漫不经心看了一眼那幅画，告诉弗兰克那画值50英镑。
segment.a: Glancing at it briefly, the dealer told him that it was worth ￡50.

segment.tip: 弗兰克几乎无法掩饰自己兴奋的心情，因为他明白自己发现了一件珍品。
segment.a: Frank could hardly conceal his excitement, for he knew that he had made a real discovery.

segment.tip: 那幅不大的画原来是柯勒乔的一幅未被发现的杰作，价值几十万英镑。
segment.a: The tiny painting proved to be an unknown masterpiece by Correggio and was worth hundreds of thousands of pounds.

segment.tip: “正义”这个词常常是同法庭连在一起的。
segment.a: The word justice is usually associated with courts of law.

segment.tip: 当某人被证据确凿地证明无罪的时候，我们也许会说正义得到了伸张。
segment.a: We might say that justice has been done when a man's innocence or guilt has been proved beyond doubt.

segment.tip: 正义是复杂的法律机器组成部分。
segment.a: Justice is part of the complex machinery of the law.

segment.tip: 那些寻求正义的人走的是一条崎岖的道路，从来没有把握他们最终将到正义。
segment.a: Those who seek it undertake an arduous journey and can never be sure that they will find it.

segment.tip: 法官无论如何聪明与有名，毕竟也是人，也会出差错的。
segment.a: Judges, however wise or eminent, are human and can make mistakes.

segment.tip: 在个别情况下，正义不再是一种抽象概念。
segment.a: There are rare instances when justice almost ceases to be an abstract concept.

segment.tip: 奖惩的实施是不受人意志支配的。
segment.a: Reward or punishment are meted out quite independent of human interference.

segment.tip: 在这种时候，正义像一种有生命的力量行使其职能。
segment.a: At such times, justice acts like a living force.

segment.tip: 当我们说“他罪有应得”这句话的时候，我们部分承认了某种特定的环境使得正义自动地起了作用。
segment.a: When we use a phrase like 'it serves him right', we are, in part, admitting that a certain set of circumstances has enabled justice to act of its own accord.

segment.tip: 一天上午，当一个小偷在一家大型珠宝店里被人抓住的时候，店员一定会忍不住说：“他罪有应得。”
segment.a: When a thief was caught on the premises of large jewellery store on morning, the shop assistants must have found it impossible to resist the temptation to say 'it serves him right.'

segment.tip: 那是一座老式的、经过改造的房子，店里有许多废置不用的大壁炉和又高又窄的烟囱。
segment.a: The shop was an old converted house with many large, disused fireplaces and tall, narrow chimneys.

segment.tip: 快到中午的时候，一个女售货员听见从一堵墙里传出一种闷声闷气的叫声。
segment.a: Towards midday, a girl heard a muffed cry coming from behind on of the walls.

segment.tip: 由于这种喊叫声重复了几次，她跑去报告经理，经理当即给消防队挂了电话。
segment.a: As the cry was repeated several times, she ran to tell the manager who promptly rang up the fire brigade.

segment.tip: 喊叫声肯定是从烟囱里传出来的，然而，因为烟囱太多，消防队员无法确定到底是哪一个。
segment.a: The cry had certainly come form one of the chimneys, but as there were so many of them, the fire fighters could not be certain which one it was.

segment.tip: 他们通过叫击烟囱倾叫声而确定传出声音的那个烟囱。
segment.a: They located the right chimney by tapping at the walls and listening for the man's cries.

segment.tip: 他们凿透了18英寸厚的墙壁，发现有个人卡在烟囱里。
segment.a: After chipping through a wall which was eighteen inches thick, they found that a man had been trapped in the chimney.

segment.tip: 由于烟囱太窄，那人无法动弹。消防队员在墙上挖了个大洞，才终于把他解救出来。
segment.a: As it was extremely narrow, the man was unable to move, but the fire fighters were eventually able to free him by cutting a huge hole in the wall.

segment.tip: 那个看来满脸沮丧、浑身漆黑的家伙从烟囱里一出来，就承认头天夜里他企图到店里行窍，但让烟囱卡住了。
segment.a: The sorry-looking, blackened figure that emerged, admitted at once that he had tried to break into the shop during the night but had got stuck in the chimney.

segment.tip: 他已经在烟囱里被困了将近10个小时。
segment.a: He had been there for nearly ten hours.

segment.tip: 甚至在那人还没被送交给警察之前，正义就已得到了伸张。
segment.a: Justice had been done even before the man was handed over to the police.

segment.tip: 我们不再像以往那样轻易相信别人了。
segment.a: We are less credulous than we used to be.

segment.tip: 在19世纪，小说家常在小说结尾处给读者准备一系列的巧合——大部分是牵强附会，极不可能的。
segment.a: In the nineteenth century, a novelist would bring his story to a conclusion by presenting his readers with a series of coincidences -- most of them wildly improbable.

segment.tip: 当时的读者却愉快地接受这样一些事实，一个低贱的女佣实际上是主人公的母亲；
segment.a: Readers happily accepted the fact that an obscure maidservant was really the hero's mother.

segment.tip: 主人公一位长期失散的兄弟，大家都以为死了，实际上一直活着，并且正在策划暗算主人公；
segment.a: A long-lost brother, who was presumed dead, was really alive all the time and wickedly plotting to bring about the hero's downfall.

segment.tip: 如此等等，
segment.a: And so on.

segment.tip: 现代读者会觉得这种天真的结局完全无法接受。
segment.a: Modern readers would find such naive solution totally unacceptable.

segment.tip: 不过，在现实生活中，有时确实会出现一些巧合，这些巧合除了19世纪小说家外谁也不会相信。
segment.a: Yet, in real life, circumstances do sometimes conspire to bring about coincidences which anyone but a nineteenth century novelist would find incredible.

segment.tip: 当我是个孩子的时候，我祖父给我讲了一位德国出租汽车司机弗朗兹。巴斯曼如何找到了据信已在20年前死去的兄弟的事。
segment.a: When I was a boy, my grandfather told me how a German taxi driver, Franz Bussman, found a brother who was thought to have been killed twenty years before.

segment.tip: 一次，他与妻子徒步旅行。途中，停下来与一个工人交谈，
segment.a: While on a walking tour with his wife, he stooped to talk to a workman.

segment.tip: 接着他们继续往前走去。巴斯曼夫人说那工人与她丈夫相貌很像，甚至猜测他可能就是她丈夫的兄弟。
segment.a: After they had gone on, Mrs. Bussman commented on the workman's close resemblance to her husband and even suggested that he might be his brother.

segment.tip: 弗朗兹对此不屑一顾，指出他兄弟已经在战争中阵亡了。
segment.a: Franz poured scorn on the idea, pointing out that his brother had been killed in action during the war.

segment.tip: 尽管巴斯曼夫人熟知这个情况，但她仍然认为自己的想法仍有百万分之一的可能性。
segment.a: Though Mrs. Busssman fully acquainted with this story, she thought that there was a chance in a million that she might be right.

segment.tip: 几天后，她派了一个男孩去问那人是否叫汉斯.巴斯曼。
segment.a: A few days later, she sent a boy to the workman to ask him if his name was Hans Bussman.

segment.tip: 不出巴斯曼夫人所料，那人的名字真是汉斯.巴斯曼，他确实是弗朗兹失散多年的兄弟。
segment.a: Needless to say, the man's name was Hans Bussman and he really was Franz's long-lost brother.

segment.tip: 兄弟俩团聚之时，汉斯说明了他活下来的经过，
segment.a: When the brothers were reunited, Hans explained how it was that he was still alive.

segment.tip: 战争即将结束时，他负伤被送进医院，并与部队失去联系。
segment.a: After having been wounded towards the end of the war, he had been sent to hospital and was separated from his unit.

segment.tip: 医院遭到轰炸，汉斯步行回到了西德。
segment.a: The hospital had been bombed and Hans had made his way back into Western Germany on foot.

segment.tip: 与此同时，他所在部队被击溃，他的所有档案材料全部毁于战火。
segment.a: Meanwhile, his unit was lost and all records of him had been destroyed.

segment.tip: 汉斯重返故里，但他的家已被炸毁，左邻右舍谁也不知原住户的下落，
segment.a: Hans returned to his family home, but the house had been bombed and no one in the neighbourhood knew what had become of the inhabitants.

segment.tip: 汉斯以为全家人都在空袭中遇难，于是便在距此50英里外的一座村子里定居下来，直至当日。
segment.a: Assuming that his family had been killed during an air raid, Hans settled down in a village fifty miles away where he had remained ever since.

segment.tip: 我们已经习惯于相信火车总是准点的。
segment.a: We have learnt to expect that trains will be punctual.

segment.tip: 经过多年的适应，大多数人对火车时刻表产生了一种不可动摇的信念。
segment.a: After years of conditioning, most of us have developed an unshakable faith in railway timetables.

segment.tip: 轮船船期可能因风暴而推延，
segment.a: Ships may be delayed by storms;

segment.tip: 飞机航班可能因恶劣天气而取消，唯有火车必然是准点的。
segment.a: flights may be cancelled because of bad weather, but trains must be on time.

segment.tip: 只有非同寻常的大雪才可能暂时打乱铁路运行。
segment.a: Only an exceptionally heavy snowfall might temporarily dislocate railway services.

segment.tip: 因此，一旦铁路上真出了问题，人们便不加思索地责备铁路当局。
segment.a: It is all too easy to blame the railway authorities when something does go wrong.

segment.tip: 事实上，差错很可能是我们自己，而不是铁路当局的。
segment.a: The truth is that when mistakes occur, they are more likely to be ours than theirs.

segment.tip: 我查看了列车时刻表，满意地了解到有一趟去威斯特海温的快车。
segment.a: After consulting my railway timetable, I noted with satisfaction that there was an express train to Westhaven.

segment.tip: 这是趟直达车，旅途总共才需1小时17分钟。
segment.a: It went direct from my local station and the journey lasted mere hour and seventeen minutes.

segment.tip: 上车后，我不禁注意到许多当地人也上了车。
segment.a: When I boarded the train, I could not help noticing that a great many local people got on as well.

segment.tip: 一开始，我并不感到奇怪，
segment.a: At the time, this did not strike me as odd.

segment.tip: 我想除我之外，想利用快车之便的也一定大有人在。
segment.a: I reflected that there must be a great many people besides myself who wished to take advantage of this excellent service.

segment.tip: 火车开出几英里即在一个小站威德里停了下来。对此，我不觉得奇怪，
segment.a: Neither was I surprise when the train stopped at Widley, a tiny station a few miles along the line.

segment.tip: 因为即便是特别快车也可能被信号拦住。
segment.a: Even a mighty express train can be held up by signals.

segment.tip: 但是，当火车一站接着一站往前蠕动时，我便产生了怀疑。我突然感到这趟快车并没以时速90英里的速度呼啸前进，而是卟哧卟哧地向前爬行，时速仅30英里。
segment.a: But when the train dawdled at station after station, I began to wonder, It suddenly dawned on me that this express was not roaring down the line at ninety miles an hour, but barely chugging along at thirty.

segment.tip: 1小时17分过去了，走了还不到一半路程。
segment.a: One hour and seventeen minutes passed and we had not even covered half the distance.

segment.tip: 我问一位乘客，这是不是开往威斯特海温的那趟快车，他说从未听说过有这么一趟快车。
segment.a: I asked a passenger if this was the Westhaven Express, but he had not even heard of it.

segment.tip: 我决定到目的地就给铁路部门提意见。
segment.a: I determined to lodge a complaint as soon as we arrived.

segment.tip: 两小时后，我气呼呼地同威斯特海温站站长说起此事。
segment.a: Two hours later, I was talking angrily to the station master at Westhaven.

segment.tip: 他说根本没有这趟车。于是我借他本人的列车时刻表，
segment.a: When he denied the train's existence, I borrowed his copy of the timetable.

segment.tip: 我带着一种胜利者的调子告诉他那趟车白纸黑字。明明白白印在时刻表上。
segment.a: There was a note of triumph in my voice when I told him that it was there in black and white.

segment.tip: 他迅速地扫视了一眼，让我再看一遍。
segment.a: Glancing at it briefly, he told me to look again.

segment.tip: 一个小小的星形符号把我的目光引到了那页底部一个说明上。
segment.a: A tiny asterisk conducted me to a footnote at the bottom of the page.

segment.tip: 上面写着：“此趟列车暂停运行。”
segment.a: It said: 'This service has been suspended.'

segment.tip: 未来的历史学家在写我们这一段历史的时候会别具一格。
segment.a: Future historians will be in a unique position when they come to record the history of our own times.

segment.tip: 对于逐渐积累起来的庞大材料，他们几乎不知道选取哪些好，
segment.a: They will hardly know which facts to select from the great mass of evidence that steadily accumulates.

segment.tip: 而且，也不必完全依赖文字材料。
segment.a: What is more, they will not have to rely solely on the written word.

segment.tip: 电影、录像、光盘和光盘驱动器只是能为他们提供令人眼花缭乱的大量信息的几种手段。
segment.a: Films, videos, CDs and CD-ROMS are just some of the bewildering amount of information they will have.

segment.tip: 他们能够身临其境般地观看我们做事，倾听我们讲话。
segment.a: They will be able, as it were, to see and hear us in action.

segment.tip: 但是，历史学家企图重现遥远的过去可是一项艰巨的任务，
segment.a: But the historian attempting to reconstruct the distant past is always faced with a difficult task.

segment.tip: 他们必须根据现有的不充分的线索进行推理。 he can deduce from
segment.a: He has to deduce what he can from the few scanty clues available.

segment.tip: 即使看起来微不足道的遗物，也可能揭示人类早期历史的一些有趣的内容。 shed light on
segment.a: Even seemingly insignificant remains can shed interesting light on the history of early man.

segment.tip: 历史学家迄今认为日历是随农业的问世而出现的，因为当时人们面临着了解四季的实际需要，
segment.a: Up to now, historians have assumed that calendars came into being with the advent of agriculture, for then man was faced with a real need to understand something about the seasons.

segment.tip: 但近期科学研究发现，好像这种假设是不正确的。
segment.a: Recent scientific evidence seems to indicate that this assumption is incorrect.

segment.tip: 长期以来，历史学家一直对雕刻在墙壁上、骨头上、古代长毛象的象牙上的点、线和形形色色的符号感到困惑不解。
segment.a: Historians have long been puzzled by dots, lines and symbols which have been engraved on walls, bones, and the ivory tusks of mammoths.

segment.tip: 这些痕迹是游牧人留下的，他们生活在从公元前约35，000年到公元前10，000年的冰川期的末期，以狩猎、捕鱼为生。
segment.a: The nomads who made these markings lived by hunting and fishing during the last Ice Age which began about 35,000 B.C. and ended about 10,000 B.C.

segment.tip: 历史学家通过把世界各地留下的这种痕迹放在一起研究，终于弄懂了这种费解的代码。
segment.a: By correlating markings made in various parts of the world, historians have been able to read this difficult code.

segment.tip: 他们发现代码与昼夜更迭和月亮圆缺有关，
segment.a: They have found that it is connected with the passage of days and the phases of the moon.

segment.tip: 事实上是一种最原始的日历。
segment.a: It is, in fact, a primitive type of calendar.

segment.tip: 大家早就知道，画在墙上的狩猎图景并不是单纯的艺术表现形式，
segment.a: It has long been known that the hunting scenes depicted on walls were not simply a form of artistic expression.

segment.tip: 它们有着一定的含义，因为它们已接近古代人的文字形式。
segment.a: They had a definite meaning, for they were as near as early man could get to writing.

segment.tip: 有时，这种图画与墙壁上的刻痕共存，它们之间可能有一定的联系。
segment.a: It is possible that there is a definite relation between these paintings and the markings that sometimes accompany them.

segment.tip: 看来人类早就致力于探索四季变迁了，比人们想像的要早20,000年。
segment.a: It seems that man was making a real effort to understand the seasons 20,000 years earlier than has been supposed.

segment.tip: 穿越平原的道路高低不平，开车走了不远，路面愈加崎岖。
segment.a: The rough across the plain soon became so bad that we tried to get Bruce to drive back to the village we had come from.

segment.tip: 我们想劝说布鲁斯把车开回我们出发的那个村庄去。尽管路面布满石头，坑坑洼洼，但布鲁斯却一点儿不慌乱。
segment.a: Even though the road was littered with boulders and pitted with holes, Bruce was not in the least perturbed.

segment.tip: 他瞥了一眼地图，告诉我们前面再走不到20英里就是一个村庄。
segment.a: Glancing at his map, he informed us that the next village was a mere twenty miles away.

segment.tip: 这并不是说布鲁斯总是低估困难，
segment.a: It was not that Bruce always underestimated difficulties.

segment.tip: 他压根儿没有一点儿危险感。
segment.a: He simply had no sense of danger at all.

segment.tip: 他认为不管路面情况如何，车必须以最高速度前进。
segment.a: No matter what the conditions were, he believed that a car should be driven as fast as it could possibly go.

segment.tip: 我们在尘士飞扬的道路上颠簸，车子东拐西弯，以躲开那些大圆石。
segment.a: As we bumped over the dusty track, we swerved to avoid large boulders.

segment.tip: 车轮搅起的石块锤击车身，发出不祥的锤击声。
segment.a: The wheels scooped up stones which hammered ominously under the car.

segment.tip: 我们想念迟早会飞起一个石块把油箱砸开一个窟窿，或者把发动机砸坏。
segment.a: We felt sure that sooner or later a stone would rip a hole in our petrol tank or damage the engine.

segment.tip: 因此，我们不时地掉过头，怀疑车后是否留下了机油和汽油的痕迹。
segment.a: Because of this, we kept looking back, wondering if we were leaving a trail of oil and petrol behind us.

segment.tip: 突然大石块不见了，前面是一片平地，唯一的障碍只有一簇簇灌木丛。这使我们长长地松了口气。
segment.a: What a relief it was when the boulders suddenly disappeared, giving way to a stretch of plain where the only obstacles were clumps of bushes.

segment.tip: 但是更糟糕的事情在等着我们，
segment.a: But there was worse to come.

segment.tip: 离我们不远处，出现一个大裂缝。
segment.a: Just ahead of us there was a huge fissure.

segment.tip: 我们再次央求布鲁斯小心，他这才把车停了下来。 renewed pleadings 再次央求
segment.a: In response to renewed pleadings, Bruce stopped.

segment.tip: 我们纷纷下车察看那个大裂缝，他却呆在车上。
segment.a: Though we all got out to examine the fissure, he remained in the car.

segment.tip: 我们告诉他那个大裂缝长50码，宽2英尺，深4英尺。
segment.a: We informed him that the fissure extended for fifty years and was two feet wide and four feet deep.

segment.tip: 这也没有对他产生任何影响。
segment.a: Even this had no effect.

segment.tip: 布鲁斯挂上慢档，把两只前轮分别搁在裂缝的两边，顺着弯弯曲曲的裂缝，以发疯的速度向前开去。
segment.a: Bruce went into a low gear and drove at a terrifying speed, keeping the front wheels astride the crack as he followed its zigzag course.

segment.tip: 我们还未来得及担心后果，车已重新开上了平地。
segment.a: Before we had time to worry about what might happen, we were back on the plain again.

segment.tip: 布鲁斯又看了一眼地图，告诉我们那座村庄离我们只有15英里了。
segment.a: Bruce consulted the map once more and told us that the village was now only fifteen miles away.

segment.tip: 下一个障碍是一片约半英里宽的浅水塘。
segment.a: Our next obstacle was a shallow pool of water about half a mile across.

segment.tip: 布鲁斯向水塘冲去，但车开到水塘当中，嘎吱一声停住了。
segment.a:
Bruce charged at it, but in the middle, the car came to a grinding halt. 
charge at 冲向 
grinding halt 戛然而止

segment.tip: 仪表盘一盏黄灯闪着刺眼的光芒，布鲁斯兴致勃勃地宣布发动机里没油了！
segment.a: A yellow light on the dashboard flashed angrily and Bruce cheerfully announced that there was no oil in the engine!

segment.tip: 谁也弄不清为什么大学生好像比任何人都更喜欢恶作剧。
segment.a: It has never been explained why university students seem to enjoy practical jokes more than else.

segment.tip: 大学生擅长一种特殊的恶作剧——戏弄人。
segment.a: Students specialize in a particular type of practical joke: the hoax.

segment.tip: 请消防队来扑灭一场根本没有的大火是一种低级骗局，有自尊心的大学生决不会去做。
segment.a: Inviting the fire brigade to put out a nonexistent fire is a crude form of deception which no self-respecting student would ever indulge in.

segment.tip: 大学生们常常做的是制造一种可笑的局面，使大家笑上一场，当然受害者是笑不出来的。
segment.a: Students often create amusing situations which are funny to everyone except the victims.

segment.tip: 最近有个学生看见两个工人在学校门外用风钻干活，马上打电话报告警察，说有两个学生装扮成工人，正在用风钻破坏路面。
segment.a: When a student recently saw two workmen using a pneumatic drill outside his university, he immediately telephoned the police and informed them that two students dressed up as workmen were tearing up the road with a pneumatic drill.

segment.tip: 挂上电话后，他又马上来到工人那儿，告诉他们若有个警察来让他们走开，不要把他当回事，
segment.a: As soon as he had hung up, he went over to the workmen and told them that if a policeman ordered them to go away, they were not take him seriously.

segment.tip: 还对工人说，有个学生常装扮成警察无聊地同别人开玩笑。
segment.a: He added that a student had dressed up as a policeman and was playing all sorts of silly jokes on people.

segment.tip: 警察与工人都对那个学生事先通报情况表示感谢。
segment.a: Both the police and the workmen were grateful to the student for this piece of advance information.

segment.tip: 那个学生躲在附近一拱形的门廊里，在那儿可以看见、听到现场发生的一切。
segment.a: The student hid in an archway nearby where he could watch and hear everything that went on.

segment.tip: 果然，警察来了，有礼貌地请工人离开此地；
segment.a: Sure enough, a policeman arrived on the scene and politely asked the workmen to go away.

segment.tip: 但其中一个工人粗鲁地回了几句。
segment.a: When he received a very rude reply from one of the workmen.

segment.tip: 于是警察威胁要强行使他们离开。
segment.a: He threatened to remove them by force.

segment.tip: 工人说，悉听尊便。警察去打电话叫人。
segment.a: The workmen told him to do as he pleased and the policeman telephoned for help.

segment.tip: 一会儿工夫，又来了4个警察，规劝工人离开。
segment.a:
Shortly afterwards, four more policemen arrived and remonstrated with the workmen.
 remonstrate 告诫

segment.tip: 由于工人拒绝停下手中的活，警察想夺风钻。
segment.a:
As the men refused to stop working, the police attempted to seize the pneumatic drill.
 pneumatic 气动的

segment.tip: 两个工人奋力抗争，其中一个发了火。
segment.a: The workmen struggled fiercely and one of them lost his temper.

segment.tip: 他威胁说要去叫警察。
segment.a: He threatened to call the police.

segment.tip: 警察听后讥讽地说，这大可不必，因为他俩已被逮捕了。
segment.a: At this, the police pointed out ironically that this would hardly be necessary as the men were already under arrest.

segment.tip: 其中一个工人装模作样地问道，在被带往警察局之前，是否可以打一个电话。
segment.a: Pretending to speak seriously, one of the workmen asked if he might make a telephone call before being taken to the station.

segment.tip: 警察同意了，陪他来到一个投币地电话前，
segment.a: Permission was granted and a policeman accompanied him to a pay phone.

segment.tip: 当他看到那个工人真的是给警察挂电话，才恍然大悟，原来他们都成一场骗局的受害者。
segment.a:
Only when he saw that the man was actually telephoning the police did he realize that they had all been the victims of a hoax. 
Only when he saw ..did he realize that ..
 only when直到…才…，只有当时候…才，only为副词，起强调作用。只有当only+状语（课文中为从属连词 when导的时间状语从句)这样的结构用于句首时，句子（或主句)的谓语部分方需使用时，使用正常的语序

segment.tip: 宁静的乡村生活从来没有吸引过我。
segment.a: The quiet life of the country has never appealed to me.

segment.tip: 我生在城市，长在城市， bred breed 培育
segment.a: City born and city bred.

segment.tip: 总认为乡村是透过火车车窗看到的那个样了，或偶尔周末去游玩一下景象。
segment.a: I have always regarded the country as something you look at through a train window, or something you occasional visit during the weekend.

segment.tip: 我的许多朋友都住在城市，但他们只要一提起乡村，马上就会变得欣喜若狂。
segment.a: Most of my friends live in the city, yet they always go into raptures at the mere mention of the country.

segment.tip: 尽管他们都交口称赞宁静的乡村生活的种种优点，但其中只有一个人真去农村住过，而且不足6个月就回来了。
segment.a: Though they extol the virtues of the peaceful life, only one of hem has ever gone to live in the country and he was back in town within six months.

segment.tip: 即使他也仍存有幻觉，好像乡村生活就是比城市生活优越。
segment.a: Even he still lives under the illusion that country life is somehow superior to town life.

segment.tip: 他滔滔不绝地大谈友好的农民，洁净的空气，贴近大自然的环境和悠闲的生活节奏。
segment.a: He is forever talking about the friendly people, the clean atmosphere, the closeness to nature and the gentle pace of living.

segment.tip: 他坚持认为，凌晨雄鸡第一声啼叫，黎明时分小鸟吱喳欢叫，冉冉升起的朝阳染红树木、牧场，此番美景无与伦比。
segment.a: Nothing can be compared, he maintains, with the first cockcrow, the twittering of birds at dawn, the sight of the rising sun glinting on the trees and pastures.

segment.tip: 但这种田园诗般的乡村风光仅仅是一个侧面。
segment.a: This idyllic pastoral scene is only part of the picture.

segment.tip: 我的朋友没有提到在电视机前度过的漫长寂寞的冬夜——电视是唯一的娱乐形式。
segment.a: My friend fails to mention the long and friendless winter evenings in front of the TV -- virtually the only form of entertainment.

segment.tip: 他也不说商店货物品种单调，以及那些每天不得不从乡下赶到城里工作的不幸的人们。
segment.a: He says nothing about the poor selection of goods in the shops, or about those unfortunate people who have to travel from the country to the city every day to get to work.

segment.tip: 人们为什么情愿每天在路上奔波4个小时去换取值得怀疑的乡间的优点，我是无法理解的。
segment.a:
Why people are prepared to tolerate a four-hour journey each day for the dubious privilege of living in the country is beyond me. 
tolerate: 忍受

segment.tip: 要是他们愿意住在本来属于他们的城市，则可以让他们省去诸多不便与节约大量开支。
segment.a:
They could be saved so much misery and expense if they chose to live in the city where they rightly belong.
misery: 苦难/不便
rightly belong: 理应属于

segment.tip: 如果你愿舍弃乡下生活那一点点乐趣的话，那么你会发出城市可以为你提供生活最美好的东西。
segment.a: If you can do without the few pastoral pleasures of the country, you will find the city can provide you with the best that life can offer.

segment.tip: 你去看朋友根本不用跋涉好几英里，
segment.a: You never have to travel miles to see your friends.

segment.tip: 他们都住在附近，你随时可以同他们聊天或在晚上一起娱乐。
segment.a: They invariably lie nearby and are always available for an informal chat or an evening's entertainment.

segment.tip: 我在乡村有一些熟人，他们每年进城来看一回或几回戏，并把此看作一种特殊的享受。
segment.a: Some of my acquaintances in the country come up to town once or twice a year to visit the theatre as a special treat.

segment.tip: 看戏在他们是件大事，需要精心计划。
segment.a: For them this is a major operation which involves considerable planning.

segment.tip: 当戏快演完时，他们又为是否能赶上末班火车回家而犯愁。
segment.a:
As the play draws to its close, they wonder whether they will ever catch that last train home.
draws to its close: 快完时

segment.tip: 这种焦虑，城里人是从未体验过的。
segment.a: The city dweller never experiences anxieties of this sort.

segment.tip: 坐公共汽车几站路，就可看到最新的展览、电影、戏剧。
segment.a: The latest exhibitions, films, or plays are only a short bus ride away.

segment.tip: 买东西也是一种乐趣。
segment.a: Shopping, too, is always a pleasure.

segment.tip: 物品种繁多，从来不必用二等品来凑合。
segment.a:
There is so much variety that you never have to make do with second best. 
make do with 凑合  
second best 第二好的东西

segment.tip: 乡里人进城采购欣喜若狂，每次回家时都买足了外来商品，直到拿不动方才罢休，连走路都摇摇晃晃的。
segment.a: Country people run wild when they go shopping in the city and stagger home loaded with as many of the exotic items as they can carry.

segment.tip: 城市也并非没有良辰美景。
segment.a: Nor is the city without its moments of beauty.

segment.tip: 寒冷潮湿的冬夜里，广告灯箱发出的暖光，会给人某种安慰。
segment.a: There is something comforting about the warm glow shed by advertisements on cold wet winter nights.

segment.tip: 周末，当成千上万进城上班的人回到他们的乡间寓所之后，空旷的街市笼罩着一种宁静气氛，没有什么能比此时的宁静更令人难忘了。
segment.a: Few things could be more impressive than the peace that descends on deserted city streets at weekends when the thousands that travel to work every day are tucked away in their homes in the country.

segment.tip: 城里人对这一切心里很明白，却偏要执拗地装出他们喜欢住在乡村的样子，这对我来说一直是个谜。
segment.a: It has always been a mystery to me who city dwellers, who appreciate all these things, obstinately pretend that they would prefer to live in the country.

segment.tip: 洞穴勘查——或洞穴勘探——是一项比较新的体育活动。
segment.a: Cave exploration, or pot-holing, as it has come to be known, is a relatively new sport.

segment.tip: 寻求独处的愿望或寻求意外发现的机会的欲望吸引人们来到地下深处。
segment.a: Perhaps it is the desire for solitude or the chance of making an unexpected discovery that lures people down to the depths of the earth.

segment.tip: 要想对洞穴探险者的动机作出满意的解释是不可能的。
segment.a: It is impossible to give a satisfactory explanation for a pot-holer's motives.

segment.tip: 对洞穴探险者来说，洞穴有一种特殊的魅力，就像高山对登山者有特殊魅力一样。
segment.a: For him, caves have the same peculiar fascination which high mountains have for the climber.

segment.tip: 为什么洞空能引发人的那种探险本能，人们对此只能有一种模模糊糊的理解。
segment.a: They arouse instincts which can only be dimly understood.

segment.tip: 探测非常深的洞穴不是那些在星期日下午漫步的人所能胜任的。
segment.a: Exploring really deep caves is not a task for the Sunday afternoon rambler.

segment.tip: 这种活动需要有军事行动般的周密布署和预见能力。
segment.a: Such undertakings require the precise planning and foresight of military operations.

segment.tip: 有时需要花费整整8天时间来搭起绳梯，建立供应基地，然后才能到一个很深的洞穴里。
segment.a: It can take as long as eight days to rig up rope ladders and to establish supply bases before a descent can be made into a very deep cave.

segment.tip: 作出这样的准备是必要的，因为无法预见到洞穴探险者究竟会遇到什么性质的困难。
segment.a: Precautions of this sort are necessary, for it is impossible to foretell the exact nature of the difficulties which will confront the pot-holer.

segment.tip: 世界上最深的洞穴是格里诺布尔附近的高弗.伯杰洞，
segment.a: The deepest known cave in the world is the Gouffre Berger near Grenoble.

segment.tip: 深达3,723英尺。
segment.a: It extends to a depth of 3,723 feet.

segment.tip: 这个深邃的洞穴是由一条地下暗泉冲刷岩石中的缝隙并使之慢慢变大而形成的。
segment.a: This immense chasm has been formed by an underground stream which has tunneled a course through a flaw in the rocks.

segment.tip: 此洞的洞口在丹芬阿尔卑斯山的高原上，
segment.a: The entrance to the cave is on a plateau in the Dauphine Alps.

segment.tip: 仅6英尺宽，很难被发现。
segment.a: As it is only six feet across, it is barely noticeable.

segment.tip: 若不是法国著名洞穴探险家伯杰由于偶然的机会发现了这个洞口的话，这个洞也许不会为人所知。
segment.a: The cave might never have been discovered has not the entrance been spotted by the distinguished French pot-holer, Berger.

segment.tip: 自从被发现以后，这个洞成了洞穴探险者的珠穆朗玛峰，
segment.a: Since its discovery, it has become a sort of potholers' Everest.

segment.tip: 人们多次进入洞内探险，但至今尚有不少东西有待勘探。
segment.a: Though a number of descents have been made, much of it still remains to be explored.

segment.tip: 最近，一队洞穴探险者下到了高弗.伯杰洞里。
segment.a: A team of pot-holers recently went down the Gouffre Berger.

segment.tip: 他们从高原上的窄缝进去，顺着笔直陡峭的洞壁往下爬。来到一条狭窄的走廊上。
segment.a: After entering the narrow gap on the plateau, they climbed down the steep sides of the cave until they came to narrow corridor.

segment.tip: 他们不得不侧着身子往前走，有时过浅溪，有时游过深潭。
segment.a: They had to edge their way along this, sometimes wading across shallow streams, or swimming across deep pools.

segment.tip: 突然，他们来到一道瀑布前，那瀑布奔泻而下，注入洞底一处地下湖里。
segment.a: Suddenly they came to a waterfall which dropped into an underground lake at the bottom of the cave.

segment.tip: 他们跳入湖中，把各种器具装上一只充气的橡皮艇，听任水流将他们带往对岸。
segment.a: They plunged into the lake, and after loading their gear on an inflatable rubber dinghy, let the current carry them to the other side.

segment.tip: 湖水冰冷刺骨，他们必须穿上一种特制的橡皮服以保护自己。
segment.a: To protect themselves from the icy water, they had to wear special rubber suits.

segment.tip: 在湖的尽头，他们见到一大堆一大堆由湖水冲刷上岸的碎石。
segment.a: At the far end of the lake, they came to huge piles of rubble which had been washed up by the water.

segment.tip: 在这儿，他们可以听见一种连续不断的轰鸣声。后来他们发现这是由山洞顶部的一个小孔里喷出的水柱跌落到水潭中发出的声音。
segment.a: In this part of the cave, they could hear an insistent booming sound which they found was caused by a small waterspout shooting down into a pool from the roof of the cave.

segment.tip: 洞穴探险者从岩石缝里挤身过去，来到一个巨大的洞里，其大小相当于一个音乐厅。
segment.a: Squeezing through a cleft in the rocks, the pot-holers arrived at an enormous cavern, the size of a huge concert hall.

segment.tip: 他们打开强力弧光灯，看见一株株巨大的石笋，有的高达40英尺，像树干似地向上长着，与洞顶悬挂下来的钟乳石相接。
segment.a: After switching on powerful arc lights, they saw great stalagmites -- some of them over forty feet high -- rising up like tree-trunks to meet the stalactites suspended from the roof.

segment.tip: 周围是一堆堆石灰石，像彩虹一样闪闪发光。
segment.a: Round about, piles of limestone glistened in all the colours of the rainbow.

segment.tip: 洞里有一种可怕的寂静，唯一的可以听见的声响是高高的圆顶上不间断地滴水的嘀嗒声
segment.a: In the eerie silence of the cavern, the only sound that could be heard was made by water which dripped continuously from the high dome above them.

segment.tip: 保险公司一般说来愿意承保一切东西。
segment.a: Insurance companies are normally willing to insure anything.

segment.tip: 承办公共财产或私人财产保险是世界上大部分国家的正常业务。
segment.a: Insuring public or private property is a standard practice in most countries in the world.

segment.tip: 如果你要举办一次露天游园会或盛宴，为避免碰上不好的天气而遭受损失也同样可以保险，
segment.a: If, however, you were holding an open air garden party or a fete it would be equally possible to insure yourself in the event of bad weather.

segment.tip: 不用说，保险公司承担风险越大，你付的保险费也就越高。
segment.a: Needless to say, the bigger the risk an insurance company takes, the higher the premium you will have to pay.

segment.tip: 航运公司为打捞沉船而提出索赔，这是常有的事，
segment.a: It is not uncommon to hear that a shipping company has made a claim for cost of salvaging a sunken ship.

segment.tip: 但某地当局为打捞一只焙制馅饼的盘子提出索赔，倒是件新鲜的事儿。
segment.a: But the claim made by a local authority to recover the cost of salvaging a sunken pie dish must surely be unique.

segment.tip: 这个馅饼盘子确实少见，有18英尺长，6英尺宽。
segment.a: Admittedly it was an unusual pie dish, for it was eighteen feet long and six feet wide.

segment.tip: 某地方当局买下它用来焙制一个巨大的馅饼为一年一度交易会助兴。
segment.a: It had been purchased by a local authority so that an enormous pie could be baked for an annual fair.

segment.tip: 馅饼委员会确认运输这只盘子的最佳方案是通过运河水运。于是，他们对这只盘子的运输安全投了保。
segment.a: The pie committee decided that the best way to transport the dish would be by canal, so they insured it for the trip.

segment.tip: 盘子下水后不久，馅饼委员会成员们来到当地一家小酒店庆贺。
segment.a: Shortly after it was launched, the pie committee went to a local inn to celebrate.

segment.tip: 就在这个时候，许多十几岁的孩子爬盘子举行他们自己的集会。
segment.a: At the same time, a number of teenagers climbed on to the dish and held a little party of their own.

segment.tip: 他们跳起了舞，盘子难以承受。舞会进行过程中，盘子倾覆，沉入了7英尺深的水中。
segment.a: Dancing proved to be more than the dish could bear, for during the party it capsized and sank in seven feet of water.

segment.tip: 馅饼委员会给当地汽车修理库老板打电话，他闻讯后开着一辆急修车前来打捞盘子。
segment.a: The pie committee telephoned a local garage owner who arrived in a recovery truck to salvage the pie dish.

segment.tip: 那些孩子们穿着湿衣服哆嗦，看着3个工人轮潜入水中以确定盘子的位置。
segment.a: Shivering in their wet clothes, the teenagers looked on while three men dived repeatedly into the water to locate the dish.

segment.tip: 他们没费多大事儿就找到了盘子。可是把盘子捞出却是一个很大的难题。
segment.a: They had little difficulty in finding it, but hauling it out of the water proved to be a serious problem.

segment.tip: 盘子四边十分光滑，要在盘边拴上绳索或链条而同时又不损坏它是很难办到的。
segment.a: The sides of the dish were so smooth that it was almost impossible to attach hawsers and chains to the rim without damaging it.

segment.tip: 不过，他们终于将链条固定在盘子的一端，一台大功率的绞车开动起来。
segment.a: Eventually chains were fixed to one end of the dish and a powerful winch was put into operation.

segment.tip: 盘子慢慢浮出水面，被轻轻地拽向运河岸边。
segment.a: The dish rose to the surface and was gently drawn towards the canal bank.

segment.tip: 在令人忐忑不安的瞬间，盘子晃晃悠悠地上了岸，但它突然失去了平衡，又跌回水中。
segment.a: For one agonizing moment, the dish was perched precariously on the bank of the canal, but it suddenly overbalanced and slid back into the water.

segment.tip: 工人们只得再来一次。
segment.a: The men were now obliged to try once more.

segment.tip: 这次，他们用沉重的金属夹子把盘子夹住，以便往盘子上安装铁链。
segment.a: This time they fixed heavy metal clamps to both sides of the dish so that they could fasten the chains.

segment.tip: 这次，盘子必须垂直吊出水面，因为盘子的一边紧靠着运河河岸。
segment.a: The dish now had to be lifted vertically because one edge was resting against the side of the canal.

segment.tip: 绞盘机再次启动，一位工人发动了急修车的引擎。
segment.a: The winch was again put into operation and one of the men started up the truck.

segment.tip: 几分钟后，盘子被成功地拽出了水面。
segment.a: Several minutes later, the dish was successfully hauled above the surface of the water.

segment.tip: 波浪从盘子两侧急涌而出，在运河里掀起一股大浪。
segment.a: Water streamed in torrents over its sides with such force that it set up a huge wave in the canal.

segment.tip: 但是当波浪从河对岸折回来时，就有再次把盘子拖进水里的危险。
segment.a: There was danger that the wave would rebound off the other side of the bank and send the dish plunging into the water again.

segment.tip: 工人们动作迅速，终于赶在那股大浪返回之前把盘子拽到了岸上。
segment.a: By working at tremendous speed, the men managed to get the dish on to dry land before the wave returned.

segment.tip: 出远门的人常常需要决定是走旱路、水路，还是坐飞机。
segment.a: People travelling long distances frequently have to decide whether they would prefer to go by land, sea, or air.

segment.tip: 很少有人能够真正喜欢坐几个小时以上的火车。
segment.a: Hardly anyone can positively enjoy sitting in a train for more than a few hours.

segment.tip: 车厢很快就变得拥挤、闷热，
segment.a: Train compartments soon get cramped and stuffy.

segment.tip: 想摆脱开旅途的困扰是很难的。
segment.a: It is almost impossible to take your mind off the journey.

segment.tip: 看书只能解决部分问题。车轮与铁轨间单调的嘎喳声很快就会送你进入梦乡。
segment.a: Reading is only a partial solution, for the monotonous rhythm of the wheels clicking on the rails soon lulls you to sleep.

segment.tip: 白天是忽睡忽醒，
segment.a: During the day, sleep comes in snatches.

segment.tip: 到了夜晚，你真想睡了，却很难入睡。 \nmanage to 设法
segment.a: At night, when you really wish to go to sleep, you rarely manage to do so.

segment.tip: 即使你走运弄到一个卧铺，夜间有一半时间你会盯着车顶那盏小蓝灯而睡不着觉；要不然就为查票摸索你的车票。
segment.a: If you are lucky enough to get a sleeper, you spend half the night staring at the small blue light in the ceiling, or fumbling to find you ticket for inspection.

segment.tip: 一旦抵达目的地，你总是疲惫不堪。
segment.a: Inevitably you arrive at your destination almost exhausted.

segment.tip: 乘汽车作长途旅行则更加不舒服，因为连看书都几乎不可能。
segment.a: Long car journeys are even less pleasant, for it is quite impossible even to read.

segment.tip: 在公路上还好，你至少能以相当快的速度安全地向前行。但旅行的大部分时间都花在路上，而且只有很少的服务设施，交通也很拥挤。
segment.a: On motorways you can, at least, travel fairly safely at high speeds, but more often than not, the greater part of the journey is spent on roads with few service stations and too much traffic.

segment.tip: 相比之下，坐船旅行或环游可以得到文明世界的各种享受。
segment.a: By comparison, ferry trips or cruises offer a great variety of civilized comforts.

segment.tip: 你可以在甲板上伸展四肢、做游戏，还能也很见到各种有趣的人，能享用各种美味佳肴——当然，这一切只有在大海风平浪静的情况下才有可能。
segment.a: You can stretch your legs on the spacious decks, play games, meet interesting people and enjoy good food -- always assuming, of course, that the sea is calm.

segment.tip: 如果大海肆虐起来，你就可能晕船，那种难受劲儿是任何一种别的旅行的方式都不会带来的。
segment.a: If it is not, and you are likely to get seasick, no form of transport could be worse.

segment.tip: 即使风平浪静，坐船旅行也要占用很长时间。
segment.a: Even if you travel in ideal weather, sea journeys take a long time.

segment.tip: 没有多少人会为享受坐船旅行的乐趣而牺牲假期的时间。
segment.a: Relatively few people are prepared to sacrifice holiday time for the pleasure of travlling by sea.

segment.tip: 飞机以危险而著称，连老资格的旅行者也怕飞机。
segment.a: Aeroplanes have the reputation of being dangerous and even hardened travellers are intimidated by them.

segment.tip: 飞机另一个缺点是昂贵。
segment.a: They also have the disadvantage of being an expensive form of transport.

segment.tip: 但就速度与舒适而言，飞机是无与伦比的。
segment.a: But nothing can match them for speed and comfort.

segment.tip: 腾云驾雾，在30，000 英尺高空以500英里的时速旅行，这种经历令人心旷神怡。
segment.a: Travelling at a height of 30,000 feet, far above the clouds, and at over 500 miles an hour is an exhilarating experience.

segment.tip: 你不必想办法去摆脱旅途的困扰，因为飞机会迅速地把你送到目的地。
segment.a: You do not have to devise ways of taking your mind off the journey, for an aeroplane gets you to your destination rapidly.

segment.tip: 几小时之内，你躺在扶手椅上，享受着旅途的欢乐。
segment.a: For a few hours, you settle back in a deep armchair to enjoy the flight.

segment.tip: 真正会享受的人还可以在某些航班上看一场电影和喝香槟。
segment.a: The real escapist can watch a film and sip champagne on some services.

segment.tip: 即使没有这些消遣条件，也总是有事可做。
segment.a: But even when such refinements are not available, there is plenty to keep you occupied.

segment.tip: 飞机上，你可以观察世界上非同寻常的奇妙的美景。
segment.a: An aeroplane offers you an unusual and breathtaking view of the world.

segment.tip: 你毫不费劲地飞越高山幽谷，
segment.a: You soar effortlessly over high mountains and deep valleys.

segment.tip: 你确能饱览大地的风貌。
segment.a: You really see the shape of the land.

segment.tip: 如果这种景色被遮住了，你可以观赏一下展现在你面前的、一望数英里的、连绵不断的云海，同时阳光灿烂，天空清澈明朗。
segment.a: If the landscape is hidden from view, you can enjoy the extraordinary sight of unbroken cloud plains that stretch out for miles before you, while the sun shines brilliantly in a clear sky.

segment.tip: 旅途平稳，丝毫不妨碍你阅读或睡眠。
segment.a: The journey is so smooth that there is nothing to prevent you from reading or sleeping.

segment.tip: 不管你打算如何消磨时间，有件事是可以肯定的，
segment.a: However you decide to spend your time, one thing is certain:

segment.tip: 即当你抵达目的地时，你感到精神焕发，毫无倦意，
segment.a: you will arrive at your destination fresh and uncrumpled.

segment.tip: 用不着因为漫长的旅途的辛苦而花几天时间休息来恢复精神。
segment.a: You will not have to spend the next few days recovering from a long and arduous journey.

segment.tip: 在民主国家里，任何限制新闻自由的企图都理所当然地受到谴责。
segment.a: In democratic countries any efforts to restrict the freedom of the press are rightly condemned.

segment.tip: 然而，这种自由很容易被滥用。
segment.a: However, this freedom can easily be abused.

segment.tip: 常人轶事往往比政治事件更能引起公众注意。
segment.a: Stories about people often attract far more public attention than political events.

segment.tip: 我们都喜欢看关于别人生活的报道，但是否同样喜欢看关于自己生活的报道，就很难说了。
segment.a: Though we may enjoy reading about the lives of others, it is extremely doubtful whether we would equally enjoy reading about ourselves.

segment.tip: 记者按事实至上的论点行事，发表有关别人生活的细节，有时会给当事人造成极大的痛苦。
segment.a: Acting on the contention that facts are sacred, reporters can cause untold suffering to individuals by publishing details about their private lives.

segment.tip: 新闻具有巨大的威力。它们不仅可以给寻常人家的生活带来重大的变化，甚至还能推翻一个政府。
segment.a: Newspapers exert such tremendous influence that they can not only bring about major changes to the lives of ordinary people but can even overthrow a government.

segment.tip: 下面这户穷人一夜之间出名发财的故事戏剧性地说明了新闻报道威力。
segment.a: The story of a poor family that acquired fame and fortune overnight, dramatically illustrates the power of the press.

segment.tip: 这户人家住在南达科他州一个人口为23，000 的小镇上，镇名为阿拜丁。
segment.a: The family lived in Aberdeen, a small town of 23,000 inhabitants in South Dakota.

segment.tip: 家里已有5个孩子，全家人常年在贫困中挣扎。
segment.a: As the parents had five children, life was a perpetual struggle against poverty.

segment.tip: 第6个孩子即将问世，他们面临着更为严峻的经济问题。
segment.a: They were expecting their sixth child and were faced with even more pressing economic problems.

segment.tip: 如果他们只添了1个孩子，这件事本来就不会引起任何人的注意。
segment.a: If they had only had one more child, the fact would have passed unnoticed.

segment.tip: 这家人会继续为克服经济上的拮据而奋斗，并默默无闻地活下去。
segment.a: They would have continued to struggle against economic odds and would have lived in obscurity.

segment.tip: 但是他们出人意料生了个五胞胎，4女1男。这事使他们的生活发生了根本的变化。
segment.a: But they suddenly became the parents of quintuplets,four girls and a boy, an event which radically changed their lives.

segment.tip: 五胞胎降生第二天，一架飞机飞抵阿拜丁，随机带来60名记者与摄影师。
segment.a: The day after the birth of the five children, an aeroplane arrived in Aberdeen bringing sixty reporters and photographers.

segment.tip: 这一家迅速出了名。
segment.a: The rise to fame was swift.

segment.tip: 电视摄像机和报纸把消息传送到全国。
segment.a: Television cameras and newspapers carried the news to everyone in the country.

segment.tip: 报纸、杂志出高价向他们购买文字、图片的独家报道权。
segment.a: Newspapers and magazines offered the family huge sums for the exclusive rights to publish stories and photographs.

segment.tip: 不但素昧平生的人寄来了大量的礼物，而且婴儿食品、婴儿肥皂制造厂商为了替自己产品做广告也寄来了大量的礼物。
segment.a: Gifts poured in not only from unknown people, but room baby food and soap manufacturers who wished to advertise their products.

segment.tip: 这家人住的旧家舍将由一座价值50万美元的新住宅所取代。
segment.a: The old farmhouse the family lived in was to be replaced by new $500,000 home.

segment.tip: 由于记者纷纷要求会见，他们不得不请了律师充当他们家的发言人举行记者招待会。
segment.a: Reporters kept pressing for interviews so lawyers had to be employed to act as spokesmen for the family at press conferences.

segment.tip: 眼下，五胞胎还静静地躺在医院婴儿室的氧气帐里，他们的父母却为这名声付出了代价，
segment.a: While the five babies were babies were still quietly sleeping in oxygen tents in hospital nursery, their parents were paying the price for fame.

segment.tip: 他们再也无法过正常的生活。
segment.a: It would never again be possible for them to lead normal lives.

segment.tip: 他们成了商业化的受害者，因为他们的名字具有了市场价值。
segment.a: They had become the victims of commercialization, for their names had acquired a market value.

segment.tip: 这些孩子立即成了商品，而不是5个新的家庭成员。
segment.a: Instead of being five new family members, these children had immediately become a commodity.

segment.tip: 现在我们自己动手做事的热情很高，结果对于专业工人的依赖越来越少了。
segment.a: So great is our passion for doing things for ourselves, that we are becoming increasingly less dependent on specialized labour.

segment.tip: 由于出版了不计其数的教人自己动手做事的书报杂志，没有人再能说对某事一无所知。
segment.a: No one can plead ignorance of a subject any longer, for these are countless do-it-yourself publications.

segment.tip: 新婚夫妇找来合适的工具和材料，喜气洋洋地开始布置新房。
segment.a: Armed with the right tools and materials, newlyweds gaily embark on the task of decorating their own homes.

segment.tip: 特别是男人，常利用空闲时间安装壁炉、布置花园、建造车库、制作家具。
segment.a: Men, particularly, spend hours of their leisure time installing their own fireplaces, laying out their own gardens; building garages and making furniture.

segment.tip: 有些热衷于自己动手的人甚至自己组装电脑。
segment.a: Some really keen enthusiasts go so far as to build their own computers.

segment.tip: 为了满足自己动手热的需要，商店不仅为初学者提供专门的咨询服务，而且为顾客准备了各种零件，供他们买回家去安装。
segment.a: Shops cater for the do-it-yourself craze not only by running special advisory services for novices, but by offering consumers bits and pieces which they can assemble at home.

segment.tip: 这些东西为人们潜在的创造力提供了一个绝妙的用武之地。但不幸的是，我们并非人人都是能工巧匠。
segment.a: Such things provide an excellent outlet for pent up creative energy, but unfortunately not all of us are born handymen.

segment.tip: 妻子常常认为她们的丈夫无比聪明能干。
segment.a: Some wives tend to believe that their husbands are infinitely resourceful and can fix anything.

segment.tip: 甚至那些连一枚钉子都钉不直的男人都被认为是天生的电工、木匠、水管工和机械师。
segment.a: Even men who can hardly drive a nail in straight are supposed to be born electricians, carpenters, plumbers and mechanics.

segment.tip: 每当电灯保险丝烧断、家具榫头松动、管道堵塞、吸尘器不动时，有些妻子认为丈夫总有办法。
segment.a: When lights fuse, furniture gets rickety, pipes get clogged, or vacuum cleaners fail to operate, some woman assume that their husbands will somehow put things right.

segment.tip: 自己动手的例子中最糟糕的是，有时甚至是男人尽管接连失败却还误以为自己什么都行，
segment.a: The worst thing about the do-it-yourself game is that sometimes even men live under the delusion that they can do anything, even when they have repeatedly been proved wrong.

segment.tip: 原因就是要面子。\n 直译 这是一个自尊心的问题，就像其他任何事情一样
segment.a: It is a question of pride as much as anything else.

segment.tip: 今年春天，妻子让我请人检查一下我家的割草机。
segment.a: Last spring my wife suggested that I call in a man to look at our lawn mower.

segment.tip: 那台割草机去年夏天就坏了，尽管我答应修，但一直没抽出时间，
segment.a: It had broken down the previous summer, and though I promised to repair it, I had never got round to it.

segment.tip: 我不愿听妻子的建议，说我自己会修。
segment.a: I would not hear of the suggestion and said that I would fix it myself.

segment.tip: 一个星期六的下午，我把割草机拉到了花园里，
segment.a: One Saturday afternoon, I hauled the machine into the garden and had a close look at it.

segment.tip: 仔细检查了一番。在我看来，只需稍加调整即可。
segment.a: As far as I could see, it needed only a minor adjustment:

segment.tip: 这儿紧紧螺丝，那儿固定一下，再加几滴油，就会像新的一样了。
segment.a: a turn of a screw here, a little tightening up there, a drop of oil and it would be as good as new.

segment.tip: 事实上，修理工作远不是那么简单。
segment.a: Inevitably the repair job was not quite so simple.

segment.tip: 修完后割草机还是纹丝不动。于是，我决定把它拆开。
segment.a: The mower firmly refused to mow, so I decided to dismantle it.

segment.tip: 一会儿工夫，割草机便被拆成一个个金属零件，乱七八糟地堆在花园里。
segment.a: The garden was soon littered with chunks of metal which had once made up a lawn mower.

segment.tip: 但我却非常高兴，
segment.a: But I was extremely pleased with myself.

segment.tip: 因为我找到了毛病所在。
segment.a: I had traced the cause of the trouble.

segment.tip: 驱动轮子的链条断了一节。
segment.a: One of links in the chain that drives the wheels had snapped.

segment.tip: 我买来一根新链条后，面临的就是如何把这些令人眼花缭乱的拼板重新组装起来。
segment.a: After buying a new chain I was faced with the insurmountable task of putting the confusing jigsaw puzzle together again.

segment.tip: 等我装完后，那台割草机仍然一动不动，对此我倒并不感到吃惊。原因很简单，因为还剩下几个形状奇特的零件似乎哪里也装不上去。
segment.a: I was not surprised to find that the machine still refused to work after I had reassembled it, for the simple reason that I was left with several curiously shaped bits of metal which did not seem to fit anywhere.

segment.tip: 我无可奈何，只好罢休。
segment.a: I gave up in despair.

segment.tip: 几个星期过去了，草长了起来。
segment.a: The weeks passed and the grass grew.

segment.tip: 妻子喋喋不休让我想点办法。我告诉她，要么买一台新割草机，要么让草长下去。
segment.a: When my wife nagged me to do something about it, I told her that either I would have to buy a new mower or let the grass grow.

segment.tip: 不用说，我家现在已被丛林包围。
segment.a: Needless to say our house is now surrounded by a jungle.

segment.tip: 深草丛中的某个地方有一台正在生锈的割草机，那就是我曾答应某日要修理的割草机。
segment.a: Buried somewhere in deep grass there is a rusting lawn mower which I have promised to repair one day.

segment.tip: 污染就是我们为这个人口过密，过度工业化的星球所付出的代价。
segment.a: Pollution is the price we pay for an overpopulated, over industrialized planet.

segment.tip: 当我们开始考虑垃圾问题时，我们只有4种对付垃圾的方法：
segment.a: When you come to think about it, there are only four ways you can deal with rubbish:

segment.tip: 倾倒、焚烧、把垃圾变成再生材料或试图少产生一些垃圾。
segment.a: dump it, burn it, turn it into something you can use again, attempt to produce less of it.

segment.tip: 我们一直在试这4种方式，但是，我们在世界范围内仅产生的垃圾的量就有把我们覆盖的危险。
segment.a: We keep trying all four methods, but he sheer volume of rubbish we produce worldwide threatens to overwhelm us.

segment.tip: 然而，垃圾只是我们这个星球的污染问题的一个方面。
segment.a: Rubbish, however, is only part of the problem of polluting our planet.

segment.tip: 日益增长的对廉价食物的需求导致了另一种形式的污染。
segment.a: The need to produce ever-increasing quantities of cheap food leads to a different kind of pollution.

segment.tip: 工业化的农作方式生产出廉价的肉类制品——牛肉、猪肉和鸡肉。
segment.a: Industrialized farming methods produce cheap meat products: beef, pork and chicken.

segment.tip: 使用杀虫剂和化肥生产出廉价的谷物和蔬菜。
segment.a: The use of pesticides and fertilizers produces cheap grain and vegetables.

segment.tip: 为了廉价食物我们付出代价已经太高了：
segment.a: The price we pay for cheap food may be already too high:

segment.tip: 牛肉中的疯牛病，鸡肉和鸡蛋中的沙门氏菌，奶制品中的利斯特杆菌。
segment.a: Mad Cow Disease (BSE) in cattle, salmonella in chicken and eggs, and wisteria in dairy products.

segment.tip: 如果你想放弃肉类而变成一位素食者，那么你可以两者择一：或是选用价格昂贵、有机培植的蔬菜，或是当你认为在享用新鲜色拉和新鲜蔬菜或饮用一杯无害的水的时候，实际上每次都不断吃进杀虫剂。
segment.a: And if you think you'll abandon meat and become a vegetarian, you have the choice of very expensive organically-grown vegetables or a steady diet of pesticides every time you think you're eating fresh salads and vegetables, or just having an innocent glass of water!

segment.tip: 但是，还有一种更加隐蔽有害的污染，它专门影响城镇地区，侵袭我们的日常生活，那就是噪音。
segment.a: However, there is an even more insidious kind of pollution that particularly affects urban areas and invades our daily lives, and that is noise.

segment.tip: 防盗警报器在白天和黑夜的任何时候都会响起来，它的作用只是骚扰过路行人，而实际上却帮助窃贼入室行窃。
segment.a: Burglar alarms going off at any time of the day or night serve only to annoy passers-by and actually assist burglars to burgle.

segment.tip: 在街上，汽车的防盗警报不断对我们吼叫，这是人们极度烦燥的一个原因，
segment.a: Car alarms constantly scream at us in the street and are a source of profound irritation.

segment.tip: 最近一个有关噪音的作用的调查（令人吃惊地）指出，夜间连续不断的狗叫声，在一个从1级至7级刻度表上应列为最严重的噪间污染。
segment.a: A recent survey of the effects of noise revealed (surprisingly?) that dogs barking incessantly in the night rated the highest form of noise pollution on a scale ranging from 1 to 7.

segment.tip: 这个调查揭示了我们所不喜欢的大量的噪间的来源：
segment.a: The survey revealed a large number of sources of noise that we really dislike.

segment.tip: 夏天呜呜作响的割草机，公寓楼里深夜聚会的喧哗声，大声吵闹的邻居，各式各样的车辆，特别是穿越寂静的村庄的集装箱卡车，从头顶飞过的飞机和直升机，被带到公共场所、音量开到最大的大功率收音机。
segment.a: Lawn mowers whining on a summer's day, late-night parties in apartment blocks, noisy neighbors, vehicles of al kinds, especially large container trucks thundering through quiet village, planes and helicopters flying overhead, large radios carried round in public places and played at maximum volume.

segment.tip: 新技术也为噪音作了它的贡献。
segment.a: New technology has also made its own contribution to noise.

segment.tip: 许多人都反对移动式电话，特别是在如饭店，公共交通车等公共场所使用移动电话。
segment.a: A lot of people object to mobile phones, especially when they are used in public places like restaurants or on public transport.

segment.tip: 用移动电话大声交谈干扰我们的思路，破坏我们和朋友在一起轻声聊天所得到的乐趣。
segment.a: Loud conversations on mobile phones invade our thoughts or interrupt the pleasure of meeting friends for a quiet chat.

segment.tip: 这个有关噪音的污染调查还揭示了一种出人意外而同时可能会引人意外而同时可能会引人发笑的老式噪音源。
segment.a: The noise pollution survey revealed a rather spurring and possibly amusing old fashioned source of noise.

segment.tip: 它竟然是鼾声。
segment.a: It turned out to be snoring!

segment.tip: 人类是这方面的罪魁祸首。
segment.a: Men were found to be the worst offenders.

segment.tip: 调查指出，20%的35岁左右的男人打鼾；
segment.a: It was revealed that 20% of men in their mid-thirties snore.

segment.tip: 而到60岁这个年龄段，这个数字上升到令人惊愕的60%。
segment.a: This figure rises to a staggering 60% of men in their sixties.

segment.tip: 与这些数字相比，只有5% 的女性经常打鼾；而其余则经常被与她们同睡、像吹号似地打着呼噜的男人吵醒或弄得睡不着。
segment.a: Against these figures, it was found that only 5% of women snore regularly, while the rest are constantly woken or kept awake by their trumpeting partners.

segment.tip: 不管噪声来自何方，有一点是肯定的： 看来寂静已变成一种珍贵的回忆。
segment.a: Whatever the source of noise, one thing is certain: silence, it seems, has become a golden memory.

segment.tip: 在这个旅游频繁的世界上，仍有成千上万个游人足迹未至的地方。
segment.a: In this much-travelled world, there are still thousands of places which are inaccessible to tourists.

segment.tip: 人们总是以为偏僻的地方的村民们热情好客。
segment.a: We always assume that villagers in remote places are friendly and hospitable.

segment.tip: 但是，那些不但与外国旅游者隔绝，而且与本国同胞隔绝的人们有可能对游客抱有敌意。
segment.a: But people who are cut off not only from foreign tourists, but even from their own countrymen can be hostile to travellers.

segment.tip: 到真正偏僻的村庄去旅游并不是一件愉快的事情。我与妻子在一次周游巴尔干半岛时对此深有体会。
segment.a: Visits to really remote villages are seldom enjoyable -- as my wife and I discovered during a tour through the Balkans.

segment.tip: 我们在一座小镇上逗留了几天，参观了附近的许多古老的教堂。
segment.a: We had spent several days in a small town and visited a number of old churches in the vicinity.

segment.tip: 这些教堂吸引大量游客，不仅是因为建筑风格奇特，而且还有大量保存完好的壁画。
segment.a: These attracted many visitors, for they were not only of great architectural interest, but contained a large number of beautifully preserved frescoes as well.

segment.tip: 我们离开小镇的前一天，镇上来了几辆满载游客的公共汽车。
segment.a: On the day before our departure, several bus loads of tourists descended on the town.

segment.tip: 人多得使我们难以忍受，于是我们决定利用最后一天去乡间一游。
segment.a: This was more than we could bear, so we decided to spend our last day exploring the countryside.

segment.tip: 我们走上了一条出镇的小路，穿过几块农田，来到一片茂密的树林。
segment.a: Taking a path which led out of the town, we crossed a few fields until we came to a dense wood.

segment.tip: 我们原以为小路会到此突然终止。没想到它到树林中继续向前延伸。
segment.a: We expected the path to end abruptly, but we found that it traced its way through the trees.

segment.tip: 我们在树林中跋涉了两个多小时，到了一条深溪边。
segment.a: We tramped through the wood for over two hours until we arrived at a deep stream.

segment.tip: 我们可以看到小路在深溪对岸继续向前伸展，但却不知如何越过这道深溪。
segment.a: We could see that the path continued on the other side, but we had no idea how we could get across the stream.

segment.tip: 突然，妻子发现岸边泊着一条小船，
segment.a: Suddenly my wife spotted a boat moored to the bank.

segment.tip: 船上有一船夫在呼呼大睡。
segment.a: In it there was a boatman fast asleep.

segment.tip: 我们轻轻地把他唤醒，请他把我们摆渡过溪。
segment.a: We gently woke him up and asked him to ferry us to the other side.

segment.tip: 一开始，他很不愿意，但经劝说，终于同意了。
segment.a: Though he was reluctant to do so at first, we eventually persuaded him to take us.

segment.tip: 顺着小路，我们来到一个座落在陡峭山坡上的小村庄。
segment.a: The path led to a tiny village perched on the steep sides of a mountain.

segment.tip: 这儿有一条未经修筑的弯弯曲曲的道路，路两边排列着一些矮小的农舍。
segment.a: The place consisted of a straggling unmade road which was lined on either side by small houses.

segment.tip: 农舍全用灰色的土坯建成，因此，即使在晴朗的蓝天底下，
segment.a: Even under a clear blue sky, the village looked forbidding, as all the houses were built of grey mud bricks.

segment.tip: 村庄看上去也会令人感到难以亲近。村里似乎无人居住，唯一的生命迹象是附近田里一只面目可憎的黑山羊，用一截短绳拴在一棵树上。
segment.a: The village seemed deserted, the only sign of life being an ugly-looking black goat on a short length of rope tied to a tree in a field nearby.

segment.tip: 我们在田边一堵东倒西歪的篱笆墙上坐下来，打开几听沙丁鱼罐头，吃了一顿野外午餐。
segment.a: Sitting down on a dilapidated wooden fence near the field, we opened a couple of tins of sardines and had a picnic lunch.

segment.tip: 突然，我注意到妻子十分惊恐。
segment.a: All at once, I noticed that my wife seemed to be filled with alarm.

segment.tip: 我抬头一看，发现我们被一群衣衫褴褛的小孩团团围住了，他们在默不作声地看着我们吃饭。
segment.a: Looking up I saw that we were surrounded by children in rags who were looking at us silently as we ate.

segment.tip: 我们给他们东西吃，客客气气地同他们交谈，但他们却一动也不动。
segment.a: We offered them food and spoke to them kindly, but they remained motionless.

segment.tip: 我认为这不过是他们在陌生人面前表现出的害羞。
segment.a: I concluded that they were simply shy of strangers.

segment.tip: 后来，我们在村里的主要街道上行走的时候，一队默不作声的孩子跟在我们后头。
segment.a: When we later walked down the main street of the villager, we were followed by a silent procession of children.

segment.tip: 刚才还似乎空荡荡的村庄一下子活跃了起来，
segment.a: The village which had seemed deserted, immediately came to life.

segment.tip: 窗口露出了一张张面孔，
segment.a: Faces appeared at windows.

segment.tip: 只穿着衬衣的男人们站在屋子外面凶狠地盯着我们，
segment.a: Men in shirt sleeves stood outside their houses and glared at us.

segment.tip: 披黑纱巾的老妇人站在门口偷偷地瞅着我们。
segment.a: Old women in black shawls peered at us from doorways.

segment.tip: 最令人害怕的是到处没有一点声音。
segment.a: The most frightening thing of all was that not a sound could be heard.

segment.tip: 毫无疑问，我们的来访是不受欢迎的。
segment.a: There was no doubt that we were unwelcome visitors.

segment.tip: 我们不需要进一步的警告了。
segment.a: We needed no further warning.

segment.tip: 便掉转身子，沿着那条主要街道加快步伐，快速地朝深溪边走去，希望船夫还在那儿等着我们。
segment.a: Turning back down the main street, we quickened our pace and made our way rapidly towards the stream where we hoped the boatman was waiting.

segment.tip: 我的姑妈哈丽特好多年前就去世了，这倒是件好事。
segment.a: It is a good thing my aunt Harriet died years ago.

segment.tip: 如果她活到今天，她将不能就她热衷的话题“佣人”发表意见了。
segment.a: If she were alive today she would not be able to air her views on her favourite topic of conversation: domestic servants.

segment.tip: 哈丽特生活在一个悠闲的年代，家务事都由雇来的佣人代劳。
segment.a: Aunt Harriet lived in that leisurely age when servants were employed to do housework.

segment.tip: 她在乡下有一幢巨大杂乱的房子，叫作“山墙庄园”。
segment.a: She had a huge, rambling country house called 'The Gables'.

segment.tip: 她对这幢房子在感情上难舍难分。房子实在太大了，但在丈夫去世多年后，她仍然执意长年住在那儿。
segment.a: She was sentimentally attached to this house, for even though it was far too big for her needs, she persisted in living there long after her husband's death.

segment.tip: 哈丽特姑妈年轻时，喜欢大摆宴席，招待宾客。
segment.a: Before she grew old, Aunt Harriet used to entertain lavishly.

segment.tip: 我小时候常去“山墙庄园”作客。
segment.a: I often visited The Gables when I was a boy.

segment.tip: 不管去多少宾客，大房子里总是收拾得干干净净。
segment.a: No matter how many guests were present, the great house was always immaculate.

segment.tip: 镶木地板洁如明镜，擦得发亮的银器陈列在明亮的玻璃柜里，连姑夫的大量藏书也保存得很好，奇迹般地一尘不染。
segment.a: The parquet floors shone like mirrors; highly polished silver was displayed in gleaming glass cabinets; even my uncle's huge collection of books was kept miraculously free from dust.

segment.tip: 哈丽特姑妈统率着一支看不见的佣人大军，他们不停地擦拭、清扫、刷洗。
segment.a: Aunt Harriet presided over an invisible army of servants that continuously scrubbed, cleaned, and polished.

segment.tip: 她称这些佣人叫“流动人口”，因为他们来匆匆，所以我甚至都没有机会知道他们的姓名。
segment.a: She always referred to them as 'the shifting population', for they came and went with such frequency that I never even got a chance to learn their names.

segment.tip: 姑妈待佣人在当时算是开明的，从来不让佣人每天工作超过8小时，但他们很难使她称心如意。
segment.a: Though my aunt pursued what was, in those days, an enlightened policy, in that she never allowed her domestic staff to work more than eight hours a day, she was extremely difficult to please.

segment.tip: 她一方面总是批评人的本性朝三暮四，另一方面她又持之以恒地寻找一个理想的佣人。即使在贝西大大地伤她的心之后，她还在找，一直到她死去。
segment.a: While she always criticized the fickleness of human nature, she carried on an unrelenting search for the ideal servant to the end of her days, even after she had been sadly disillusioned by Bessie.

segment.tip: 贝西在哈丽特家干了3年。
segment.a: Bessie worked for Aunt Harriet for three years.

segment.tip: 在此期间，她赢得了姑母的赏识，甚至当上了大管家。
segment.a: During that time she so gained my aunt's confidence that she was put in charge of the domestic staff.

segment.tip: 哈丽特不知该用什么言辞来赞扬贝西的勤奋与高效。
segment.a: Aunt Harriet could not find words to praise Bessie's industriousness and efficiency.

segment.tip: 贝西除了有各种本领以外，还是一个烹饪大师。
segment.a: In addition to all her other qualifications, Bessie was an expert cook.

segment.tip: 她担任“理想仆人”角色3年之后，哈丽特终于发现她有“小小的弱点”。
segment.a: She acted the role of the perfect servant for three years before Aunt Harriet discovered her 'little weakness'.

segment.tip: 一次，姑妈有一个星期没在“山墙庄园”住。一天下午，她出其不意地回来了，带来一大批客人，吩咐贝西准备晚饭。
segment.a: After being absent from The Gables for a week, my aunt unexpectedly returned one afternoon with a party of guests and instructed Bessie to prepare dinner.

segment.tip: 结果，不仅饭菜远不如平时做得好，而且贝西走起路来似乎东倒西歪。
segment.a: Not only was the meal well below the usual standard, but Bessie seemed unable to walk steadily.

segment.tip: 她撞到了家具上，嘴里还不断咕咕哝哝议论客人。
segment.a: She bumped into the furniture and kept mumbling about the guests.

segment.tip: 当她端着最后一道菜——一大盘布丁——走进屋来时，在地毯上绊了一跤。布丁飞到半空，从姑母身边擦过，然后狠狠地砸在餐桌上。
segment.a: When she came in with the last course -- a huge pudding -- she tripped on the carpet and the pudding went flying through the air, narrowly missed my aunt, and crashed on the dining table with considerable force.

segment.tip: 这件事引起了客人们的欢笑，但哈丽特却着实吓了一跳。
segment.a: Though this caused great mirth among the guests, Aunt Harriet was horrified.

segment.tip: 她不得不认定贝西是喝醉了。
segment.a: She reluctantly came to the conclusion that Bessie was drunk.

segment.tip: 客人们自然从贝西为他们开门那一刻起就看出来了，在好长一段时间里，即最后这个乱子发生前，他们努力克制才没笑出声来。
segment.a: The guests had, of course, realized this from the moment Bessie opened the door for them and, long before the final catastrophe, had had a difficult time trying to conceal their amusement.

segment.tip: 贝西当即被解雇了。
segment.a: The poor girl was dismissed instantly.

segment.tip: 贝西走后，哈丽特姑妈发现在贝西以前用过的衣柜里整整齐齐地放着一堆堆形状各导、大小不一的酒瓶子。
segment.a: After her departure, Aunt Harriet discovered that there were piles of empty wine bottles of all shapes and sizes neatly stacked in what had once been Bessie's wardrobe.

segment.tip: 这些酒瓶神不知鬼不觉地从酒窖来到了这里。
segment.a: They had mysteriously found their way there from the wine cellar!
